leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 57.3] r 57.3 Parties to proceedings on application under section 41 or 54 (cf SCR Part 76, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Parties to proceedings on application under section 41 or 54 (cf SCR Part 76, rule 9)

p.text: If an application is made under section 41 of the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009, the person in respect of whom the application is made must be made a defendant.
[subr (1) am Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[25], effective 8 October 2009]
If an application is made under section 54 of the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009, the person in respect of whom the application is made must be made a defendant but need not be served.
[subr (2) am Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[26], effective 8 October 2009]

Before proceedings are commenced for the appointment of a manager or guardian it is prudent for the proposed plaintiff to discuss the proposal with the NSW Trustee and Guardian (previously the Office of the Protective Commissioner). Contact details for the NSW Trustee and Guardian are available at http://www.tag.nsw.gov.au/ . Pro forma documents are usually available.

In the absence of special circumstances it is undesirable for a solicitor to apply personally for protective relief in respect of their own client: McD v McD [1983] 3 NSWLR 81 . See also P v R [2003] NSWSC 819; BC200305145 at [68] and following.

A plaintiff should be careful to ensure strict compliance with the rules regarding service on an alleged incapable person or defendant. Personal service on that person is ordinarily insisted upon in order to minimise the risk, hopefully remote, that the power to appoint a manager has not been invoked without proper cause and contrary to the best interests of the person: Re Craven (1901) 18 WN (NSW) 243 . Neither the nature and scope of the person’s property interests, nor delay in obtaining medical evidence, will ordinarily provide justification for departing from the usual requirement of personal service: Re AH (an alleged incapable person) (1905) 22 WN (NSW) 68. Neither will the apprehension that service of the proceedings might create or exacerbate the defendant’s antipathy towards the plaintiff in the proceedings: Re Craven (1901) 18 WN (NSW) 243 . (Although it has been said that the proceedings should not be served on an allegedly incapable person by the plaintiff themselves: Re An Alleged Incapable Person (1959) 76 WN 447.) Note, however, that there is some North American authority for the proposition that personal service on an allegedly incapable person may be dispensed with where there is proper reason to conclude that it would dangerously excite that person: Re Webb (1906) 12 OLR 194; Re Bulger (1911) 1 WWR 248.

level.toc-caption: [57.3.15] Service of proceedings on incapable person’s next of kin

p.text: Legislation cited in [57.3.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 57.11, UCPR rr 57.4, 57.5(a)(iii).

heading.title: Service of proceedings on incapable person’s next of kin

p.text: As a general rule, the summons and supporting affidavit should be served on all the adult next of kin within the jurisdiction, unless there is evidence to show they are supporting the summons: Re ES (1906) 23 WN (NSW) 23; Re Webster (1900) 16 WN (NSW) 229 ; Re Moore (No 2) (1902) 19 WN (NSW) 277. UCPR rr 57.4 and 57.5(a)(iii) involve an obligation to give notice of an application for an order for management of the estate of a person incapable of managing their own affairs or for the appointment of a guardian of a protected person: Holt v Protective Cmr (1993) 31 NSWLR 227; BC9305256 . Similar notice may be desirable of an application for removal of a manager or the NSW Trustee and Guardian, or under UCPR r 57.11 for setting aside or varying an order for appointment of a manager.

The basic procedure for applicants seeking a private manager is set out in Re L [2000] NSWSC 721; BC200004141 . The standard of proof applied in determining whether or not a person is incapable of managing their affairs is the civil standard of proof on the balance of probabilities: McD v McD [1983] 3 NSWLR 81 .

heading.title: Appointment of a manager or guardian

p.text: The appointment of a manager under the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009 (or a guardian under the Supreme Court’s inherent jurisdiction — see Guardianship Act 1987 s 8 ) directly impacts on the person’s freedom of decision making in relation to their estate or personal circumstances. The court will be typically concerned to confine the restrictive contents of any orders to the matters necessary to cover the best interests of the person. To this extent it may be appropriate to consider whether a manager appointed under NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009 s 41 or 54 has functions in relation to the whole, or only part, of a person’s estate. In the case of an application for the appointment of a guardian (either under the Supreme Court’s inherent jurisdiction or the appeal jurisdiction under Guardianship Act 1987 s 67 ) the power is subject only to the threshold satisfaction that the person “is in need of a guardian” — see Guardianship Act 1987 s 14 . That criterion does not limit the power to satisfaction that the person concerned suffers from a relevant incapacity attributable to mental illness (the criterion that applied to orders under the former Protected Estates Act 1983 s 68 ). Nevertheless, questions of need for guardianship will frequently arise in a context that will require consideration of the existence and significance of any "mental illness". To that extent both appointments of managers and appointments of a guardian may require consideration not only of the concept of “mental illness” (RAP v AEP [1982] 2 NSWLR 508 ; PY v RJS [1982] 2 NSWLR 700 ; GPG v ACF [1983] 1 NSWLR 54 ; DW v JMW [1983] 1 NSWLR 61 ; CF v TCML [1983] 1 NSWLR 138 ; McD v McD [1983] 3 NSWLR 81 ; CCR v PS (No 2) (1986) 6 NSWLR 622 ; see also (1968) 42 ALJR 207; article by Myers J in (1961) 3 Bar Gaz) but also Mental Health Act 2007 Ch 3 (dealing with involuntary admission and treatment).

In proceedings to which this Part applies, the court exercises its discretion as to costs by determining what, in all the circumstances, is the proper order to be made: RH v CAH [1984] 1 NSWLR 694 at 708 . A failure to consider an offer of settlement of proceedings is a relevant consideration: MB v Protective Cmr [2000] NSWSC 882; BC200005206 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 57.4] r 57.4 Business concerning application under section 41 in the absence of the parties (cf SCR Part 76, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Business concerning application under section 41 in the absence of the parties (cf SCR Part 76, rule 10)

p.text: If:
the plaintiff claims a declaration and order under section 41 of the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009, and
no appearance is entered within the time limited for appearance, and
there is no attendance, at the time appointed by the originating process for the hearing, by any person opposing the claim,
the Supreme Court may determine or deal with the application in the absence of the parties and without any attendance by or on behalf of any person.
[r 57.4 am Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[27], effective 8 October 2009]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 57.5] r 57.5 Evidence in support of application under section 41 or 54 (cf SCR Part 76, rule 11)

leg:heading.title: Evidence in support of application under section 41 or 54 (cf SCR Part 76, rule 11)

p.text: The evidence in support of an application under section 41 or 54 of the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009 must include the following:
an affidavit or affidavits setting out:
the conduct and conversation or conversations claimed to establish that the defendant is incapable of managing his or her affairs, and
the nature and amount of the property of the defendant, and
the names of the defendant’s nearest relatives, so far as they are known, and the attitude of each of them to the application, and
the name of, and reason for selecting, the proposed manager,
the affidavits of at least 2 medical practitioners or other persons qualified to give an expert opinion on the defendant’s condition, each of whom must set out:
his or her formal qualifications, the extent of his or her experience in practice and his or her special qualifications in regard to questions relating to the defendant’s condition, and
his or her diagnosis of the defendant’s condition, explained in his or her own words and set out in his or her own handwriting, and
that, in his or her opinion, the defendant is incapable of managing his or her affairs, and
the reasons for that opinion or the tests on which that opinion is based, set out in his or her own words and handwriting,
except where the proposed manager is:
the NSW Trustee and Guardian, or
[repealed]
a trustee company,
the affidavits of at least 2 persons as to the fitness of the proposed manager,
except where the proposed manager is:
the NSW Trustee and Guardian, or
the plaintiff,
a consent executed by the proposed manager and an affidavit verifying the execution of the consent.
[subr (1) am Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[28]–[31], effective 8 October 2009]
Subrule (1)(a) and (b) do not apply to an application under section 54 of the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009.
[subr (2) am Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[32], effective 8 October 2009]
The affidavit of the medical practitioner must be based upon a personal examination of the allegedly incapable person: Re WM (1903) 3 SR (NSW) 552 .

Where there is no real dispute in relation to medical evidence, or there is no great divergence between the medical evidence and previous findings in a common law trial, the court may adopt the latter evidence as the basis upon which to found a decision and to make orders: MS v ES [1983] 3 NSWLR 199 ; McD v McD [1983] 3 NSWLR 81 , referred to in Attorney-General (NSW) v S (unreported, Powell J, 15 November 1984).
The forms of affidavits and consents are set out as Supreme Court Forms 78–81 (behind guide card "Forms" in Vol 3).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 57.6] r 57.6 Appointment of managers under section 52 (cf SCR Part 76, rule 12)

leg:heading.title: Appointment of managers under section 52 (cf SCR Part 76, rule 12)

p.text: If it appears expedient:
that several persons should be appointed managers pursuant to a special order referred to in section 52 of the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009, and
that one or more of them should continue to act after the death or discharge of the others, or any of them,
the order appointing the manager may direct that, after any such death or discharge, the surviving or continuing manager or managers are to continue to act.
[r 57.6 am Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[33], effective 8 October 2009]

The duty of the court, in appointing a manager or managers, is to ensure that the administration of a protected person's estate will be as simple and inexpensive as possible consistent with the proper administration of the estate. Accordingly, the court will not ordinarily appoint more than one manager unless the interests of the protected person so require: RAP v AEP [1982] 2 NSWLR 508 .

In the absence of special circumstances a member of the protected person's family may be appointed as his or her manager. Where such an appointment would be undesirable the NSW Trustee and Guardian (previously the Protective Commissioner) may be an appropriate appointment: RH v CAH [1984] 1 NSWLR 694 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 57.7] r 57.7 “Usual orders” under sections 41 and 54 (cf SCR Part 76, rules 13 and 13A)

leg:heading.title: “Usual orders” under sections 41 and 54 (cf SCR Part 76, rules 13 and 13A)

p.text: If:
under section 41 of the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009, the Supreme Court makes a declaration that the defendant is incapable of managing his or her affairs, or
under section 54 of the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009, the Supreme Court makes a declaration that the defendant is a missing person,
it may, with or without further order, also make the usual orders.
[subr (1) am Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[34], [35], effective 8 October 2009]
The usual orders referred to in subrule (1) are as follows:
an order that the defendant’s estate be subject to management under the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009,
an order that:
the person proposed in the originating process be appointed manager of the defendant’s estate, to act in relation thereto under the order and direction of the NSW Trustee and Guardian, or
if the NSW Trustee and Guardian is the person proposed, that the management of the defendant’s estate be committed to the NSW Trustee and Guardian,

if the person appointed manager of the defendant’s estate is not the NSW Trustee and Guardian, an order that the person may not do anything in reliance on the appointment until the NSW Trustee and Guardian has authorised the person to assume management of the defendant’s estate,
if 2 or more persons are appointed to be managers, an order that, on the death or discharge of any of them, custody of the defendant’s estate continues to the remainder of them,
an order that the plaintiff’s costs (and, if the defendant appears, the defendant’s costs) on an indemnity basis be paid out of the defendant’s estate,
an order that all parties be at liberty to apply as they may be advised.
[subr (2) am Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[36]–[38], effective 8 October 2009]

Unless and until an order for management of the estate of a "Protected Person" under the NSW Trustee and Guardianship Act 2009 (previously the Protected Estates Act 1983) is revoked, such person is to be conclusively presumed to be incapable in law of doing an act which would affect that estate: JNRD and the Protected Estates Act (1992) 28 NSWLR 728; BC9203262 .

level.toc-caption: [57.7.15] Orders for management of estate of person incapable of managing own affairs (NSW Trustee and Guardianship Act 2009 s 41; previously Protected Estates Act 1983 s 13)

heading.title: Orders for management of estate of person incapable of managing own affairs (NSW Trustee and Guardianship Act 2009 s 41; previously Protected Estates Act 1983 s 13)

p.text: Subject to jurisdictional limitations, the relief the court may grant is a matter of discretion to be exercised in the interests of the incapable person: M v M [1981] 2 NSWLR 334 ; Re An Incapable Person D [1983] 2 NSWLR 590; (1983) 9 Fam LR 396; 74 FLR 413 . The court may make a wide range of orders, including interlocutory orders for the appointment of a receiver and manager of property: GNM v ER [1983] 1 NSWLR 144 ; orders as to the property of protected persons resident outside the State: MS v ES [1983] 3 NSWLR 199 ; Re FN [1984] 3 NSWLR 520 ; orders authorising ex gratia payments out of the estate of a protected person to persons in whose care he or she may be: Re ES [1984] 3 NSWLR 341 ; and orders for access to a protected person: RH v CAH [1984] 1 NSWLR 694 .

The security a manager is required to provide must be appropriate to the circumstances of the particular case. This may require a balance to be struck between the need to ensure the incapable person is provided with effective security and the undesirability of unnecessarily restricting the free use of the manager's assets: Re McL [2001] NSWSC 280; BC200101621 (the judgment also sets out the basic procedure required on an application for the appointment of a private manager). The usual order ought to provide for security acceptable to the court, since the NSW Trustee and Guardian (previously the Protective Commissioner) acts as a delegate of the court in accepting security: Re McL , above.

level.toc-caption: [57.7.25] Setting aside sale etc by a protected person

heading.title: Setting aside sale etc by a protected person

p.text: In Protective Cmr v David (1993) 30 NSWLR 417 the court set aside a transfer of real property made by a person who was found to be suffering mental illness and incapable of managing her own affairs. In so doing, the court confirmed that a protected person has no power to defy the authority of the appointed manager. (Note that consideration of the indefeasibility of title and the Real Property Act 1900 specially in relation to bona fide purchasers without notice and mortgagees was not dealt with by the court.)

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 57.8] r 57.8 Evidence in support of application under section 86 (cf SCR Part 76, rules 19 and 20)

leg:heading.title: Evidence in support of application under section 86 (cf SCR Part 76, rules 19 and 20)

p.text: The evidence in support of an application under section 86 of the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009 must include the following:
the affidavits of at least 2 medical practitioners or other persons qualified to give an expert opinion on the defendant’s condition, each of whom must state:
his or her formal qualifications, the extent of his or her experience in practice and his or her special qualifications in regard to questions relating to the condition of the protected person, and
that, in his or her opinion, the protected person is capable of managing his or her affairs, and
the reasons for that opinion or the tests on which that opinion is based, set out in his or her own handwriting,
the affidavits of members of the defendant’s family or other persons, each of whom must state:
what opportunity he or she has had of assessing whether or not the protected person is capable of managing his or her affairs, and
his or her assessment and the facts, grounds and circumstances on which he or she made his or her assessment, and
any other facts that may be relevant.
[r 57.8 am Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[39], effective 8 October 2009]
Legislation cited in [57.8.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009 s 86.

Where a protected person demonstrates that they are capable of managing their affairs they are entitled to have orders made under NSW Trustee and Guardianship Act 2009 s 86 (previously Protected Estates Act 1983 s 35) revoking any declaration of incapacity and terminating management of their estate: PY v RJS [1982] 2 NSWLR 700

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 57.9] r 57.9 Mode of making application under section 87 (cf SCR Part 76, rules 23A and 23B)

leg:heading.title: Mode of making application under section 87 (cf SCR Part 76, rules 23A and 23B)

p.text: An application under section 87 of the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009 is to be made by motion in the proceedings in which the declaration and order under section 54 of that Act were made.
[subr (1) am Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[40], [41], effective 8 October 2009]
Notice of the motion is to be served on the manager or on the person on whose application the declaration and order were made.
